messageBody:
Speaking of dates, how do you recommend dealing with dates for
database driven applications, for example a browser based web
application?

In the past, I have used a SystemTime class that enhances DateTime
class for testing by allowing a test to
SystemTime.setNowTo(aFixedDateTime). In normal use, the SystemTime
class would simply return DateTime.Now.

In talking with a collegue about this subject, he was against
referring to DateTime within your application code, but rather, to
user the provided Now() feature of Sql itself. He pointed out that
the subject bug with using a SystemTime type class is that your data
because less reliable if you farm your web servers (as each server may
have a slightly different time).

The issue of requiring specific dates get compounded even further if
your application takes action based on durations (not just tracking a
specific point in time). For instance, sending out reminders to
people that haven't logged in, in 6 month. I am thinking about
creating a SqlTime that behaves similar to DateTime except it returns
a string representing the time. So, within the real world, that
string will be the pre-defined NOW() function whereas in a test, it
will resemble something like '2001-01-03 15:45'.

Any thoughts?


andrew f
